intro: Lippia bellatula, commonly known as the Mexican blueweed, is a flowering plant native to Central America and parts of the southern United States. It is a member of the Verbenaceae family and typically grows in dry, rocky soils. The plant produces small, blue to purple flowers that bloom in summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its leaves are often used in traditional herbal remedies for their aromatic and medicinal properties. Lippia bellatula is also valued in horticulture for its ornamental appeal and ability to thrive in arid conditions.
